description: Literature provides rich resources for thinking through central philosophical questions, including
the metaphysics and ethics of freedom; the problem of evil; the role of character in choice and
action; the nature of morality; rebellion and human solidarity; God's existence and relation to the
world; and the nature of truth.  Designed primarily for first-year students, this course explores
philosophical ideas in literary works of several different genres by studying plot, character,
point of view, imagery, and symbolism.  Offered during Interim.
